values:
I finally have a fairly-official-looking online portfolio: www.portablecity.net

...yep.

Sorry kids. I found Wordpress. I found free image hosting. I found open source. I've moved on.

I love my LJ friends list, and I read it daily, but I'm constraining most of my internet activity to posting art or crafts (or occasionally party photos oh facebook, but we all have our weaknesses!) - and I'm doing that posting in two places.

1.) My new wordpress blog.
2.) My etsy.com store.

So, not that my updates are much more regular, but that's where you'll find them in future!

Thanks kids, and don't stop posting - I read you all every day at work. Seriously. Gets me through.

:)n

Well there was no way I was going to post after all those helpful comments and admit I was too scared and too well-paid to quit my job... but yes, I'm still at the same job. A few changes were made and it's back to a bearably shitty job. I guess I just feel bad I don't give as big a shit as some of my coworkers - though we're in agreement that it's quite a mess there right now.

But I'm attempting (and largely succeeding) in staying distracted. For one, Em and I threw our yearly cocktail party! Except it was more like Em and Ed threw it and I stopped in to help set up and cut things up for the fondue. Yes, I said fondue. I took a few photos of Ed's handywork, for your entertainment.

I'm working on setting up a weekly craft thing with the CONC Women's Hostel, but with overtime at work and a few personal things going on, I've been late getting it going. Hopefully next Sunday I'll be knitting with these women, though. I have a big yarn donation from Knit-o-matic, which is greatly appreciated and looks like a great stash to start with. If you have a favourite online knitting tutorial, especially one with great diagrams and minimal text, let me know. I'm going to photocopy some handouts so that the women have something to refer to between sessions. I hope they're as interested in this as I am!

There is always the ongoing adventure of MONDO, of course, as well. We published books for Canzine (more than a month ago now!) as well as printed postcards and buttons, which was a big exciting project. I remembered how much I enjoy magazine layout, and let me tell you, I miss it every time I sit down and hard code articles for six hours. Which is once a week. Rumour has it that a database isn't far off, though, so hopefully update time will go down and external project time can go up proportionately. You'll know when it hits, though, because that's when Miles and I will disappear for two weeks into a serious coding adventure, and then emerge with the prettiest damn website you ever did see.

I'm starting to think about christmas presents, now. Have any of you started your shopping? How's that going?

So I'm skipping work today.

I hate my job. I need to put in my two weeks and find something, anything else. 

Does anyone have an suggestions? Ideally I'd like to teach community art classes, or do illustration or community mural work. I also accept that I will probably end up serving coffee for part of this winter. How can I best combine the two?

Or is cbc radio3 repeating songs a lot more than it used to, now it has djs? ....this is me asking if this independent radio station is overplaying independent music on the internet. Okay, now the question is: do I have a problem?
I'll step on strangers' toes instead.

Who wants to read Lost Girls next?

I'm going to sit on a full review, probably for MONDO (or maybe just to sort it all out in my mind) and just give youa once-over here.

My biggest question is honestly, what was the point? Where was this book going? Three graphic (VERY graphic) graphic novels, hardcover bound in a box set, and I was (absurdly?) expecting some sort of resolution - some sort of satisfaction (haha!) some sort of climax at least! This book left me without any catharsis, because I'm still not sure what the problems were.

Three grown women, who are AT THAT VERY MOMENT doing quite absurd sexual things to one another, apparently tirelessly, are not going to shock me with revelations from their past. If they felt at any point that they were living too hedonistic a life, the events under which they were relating that regret were, certainly, incredibly hedonistic.

The content was, I think, supposed to be shocking, but within a few pages I was quite numb to it all. Moore quickly blurred the lines between kinky sex and violence, partnership and prostitution, between threesomes, foursomes, orgies and gang-rape, between having sex ON drugs and having sex FOR drugs... and it was all rather grossly enmeshed in ideas of trauma. Never was there an exploration of healthy relationships, healthy sex, healthy sexuality - these women were empowered, but they were dangerous the whole time.

There was something incredibly misogynistic about the whole thing, even though the three main characters were women. There was this weird sense that they were held up as moral measuring sticks and that they had all failed, and won, and failed again, and essentially given up. But they weren't forgiven.

I don't know. I mean, writing anything about the sex lives of three women doing kinky things in 1914 is going to create a context of secrecy, guilt and conspiracy (arguably it doesn't matter when you set it) and inevitably.... it is going to get ugly.

And this is my other problem. The art.

The art got stronger (thank god) but I don't know if it ever got better. This story  had many problems, but the art is what made the tone so unclear. If you draw it like a fairy tale illustration then yes, some of the images are going to be shocking (the things these people do!) but three books of them makes you numb, and I felt that the art style served only for that shockingness and didn't enhance much else. Anyways, the best parts were the weird, kinky chapter splash illustrations that were the most overt bridge between the three womens' stories and the original stories of Wendy, Dorothy and Alice.

....am I glad I read it? Well I was curious, but it... wasn't rewarding in the ways I'd hoped for. That said, if you want three books of women having their way with one another, here you are.

Gut reaction: 1) it's pretentious. 2) it's pretty smart, I guess. 3) it's kind of awkward. 4) the art is inadequate. I don't know what would have been better, but...

And yeah, Moore does not like his characters, or his reader.

So, $30 worth of reading? I dunno, not really. Maybe the other two books will be better... or at least more interesting. He's just not making me THINK yet.

Tomorrow I am going to dig up old maps, maybe buy some old ones from a used book store. Then i'm going to stick a few to my canvasses with glue and acrylic medium. Then I'm going to slowly assemble a painting space. Then I will start to draw figures over the maps, and paint them in slowly in translucent layers.

I will also start to read my ubercomic.

I might also sit in a cafe with my laptop and edit interviews.

It's going to be lovely.

Too bad I have to work.

dude I totally interviewed all these awesome people today!

Shannon Gerard
Danielle Corsetto
John Martz
Joey Comeau
Becky Cloonan
Rich Stevens

Yep, nerds are awesome. Who next?!
I hope that this kick in the pants will keep me going. Everyone else has revved right up and I need to do the same thing.

I keep trying to type "goddammit" into my word processor, and it keeps autocorrecting to "goldsmith".

Weird.

I need to sell these puppies - they're NOT helping my starved libido by hanging around my apartment. If they are avatars, they are avatars of a hedonistic part of me that borders on self-destructive. They are not the long term series I am looking for, and there is a reason I have not made one of my own volition in quite some time. Goodbye, Cosmo Pillows.

(Anyone want to buy one? I have the red and the gold one still, and if they don't sell here I'll set them up on Etsy and hopefully eventually that will be that, I guess.)
I am so mad I had to take off my glasses.

I'm promising myself I'll write more, just in general, and since this is what LJ's for (right? writing?) hopefully something entertaining will appear here for people on my friends' list.

My N.D.A.'d job is going well so far - I'm learning the machines and the procedure and the programs, and getting to know my coworkers. My supervisor is a delightful lady who is capable of laughing at the ins and outs of print production drama, and she definitely makes us all feel like we're part of a team here in production. Some days are rather dull, but so far that's the worst of it. I was getting a bit tired of the 8:30-5 routine, but now for the month of July we're on odd hours (with a sprinkling of overtime...) so that's almost a relief, to be honest! Like, this week I'm working 10-6:30 for three days, and then 6-2:30 for the fourth, and while that won't be a party it will be interesting and should keep me awake.

On a related note, I've lost my daytimer. I'm confident it is somewhere in my bedroom, but after turning half the room upside down as I assembled a wardrobe this weekend, I have to admit that it is most likely behind the dresser, which is going to be a challenge to move. So if I've missed dates, or been hesitant to commit to anything, it's because I don't have a clue what I've committed to already, and I'm too stubborn to buy a new daytimer when I have six good months left in this one, and all my friends' birthdays already entered. Also it was a moleskin, and it has this swanky pocket... I'll have the energy to move my dresser after I've tidied and cleaned enough of my stuff to have a place to put everything currently piled onto my dresser, I think.

With the addition of a wardrobe to my room I am feeling much, much more at home. The wardrobe adventure was lovely, as well, in that Dan helped me carry it (despite belt problems)  and it was on sale. So I saved lots and lots of money on this wardrobe, which I then spent on a dress and a nice shirt and flipflops and a Kid Koala concert and drinks at the concert and so on and so forth and now I'm broke again. Which is okay, because I need to eat more food from home as it stands. Home's getting homey-er, as we get stuff up on the walls, find a routine with each other, work out how to keep the kitchen clean, and I actually start contributing to the cleaning schedule on the board. Having helped Miles paint most of his apartment, I do feel the itch to do the same to ours, but not until I get a steady balance in my bank account, I think. In addition to paint, we still need a toaster, a kettle and a tv with a dvd player at least. Next time I'm in Oakville I'll see what my family's not using. My bedroom itself is still chaotic, but step by step it's coming together. I got rid of the last big box, now I'm left with assorted shoeboxes and as such to empty and put away. Amazing how long it takes to move in, eh? Just boggling.
I had the realization a few weeks ago that I am living my childhood dream. How so, you ask? Well, all I really wanted was a place of my own in Toronto, a neighbourhood to wander with friends nearby, room to do art and roommates to do it with, and income that didn't suck the soul from me in return. I know, I wasn't a big dreamer as a child. I guess I wanted a flowery romance, too, but at least I have the room for a flowery romance in my life now, if not the actual product. Like that space above my aloe plant I'm reserving for an awesome print - I trust it will be there eventually. But now that I've achieved my dream, what the hell do I do with myself?

Tough question.

This week had been proof that I've done it, though. I've been out almost every night, seeing live music and theatre, going drinking and eating out, shopping for snazzy clothes in weird stores (also Dufferin Mall, which was not, I do admit, ever a part of my childhood dreams) ... and, well, it's been expensive, is the sad part. More expensive than I can afford right now. So, cut back on the shopping, the eating out, take more pride in my cooking (haha! ha!) and have at-home activities more often. And yesterday afternoon that's what I did: my main purchase was a coffee while I sat and knitted in the Concord for an hour, and then I came home, made some soup and listened to CBC's Saturday Night Blues Show and continued with the knitting, waiting to see if something would pop into my head to draw.

I think I can learn to budget. The hardest part is lunches at work - I really hate sandwiches. Breakfast is tough too, cause I sleep in and have to rush there and end up eating chips and a pop on the bus up. I'm going to try walking there this week, at least for the 10AM shifts. It'll be good for me, and it will give me time to eat an apple along the way. If I get the energy to hit up No Frills I'll pick up some no-name bulk granola bars and muffins, and between the three I should be fed every morning for the week. Shopping this week was an indulgence because I got a government check and didn't think to just put it towards my Visa, but to be honest I really did need this damn wardrobe. The dress, shirt and flipflops were less necessary, I admit. I should put shopping aside for now. I should replace it with crafting! But the trouble with crafting is you get halfway into a project only to discover you need to purchase some key element and suddenly your money-saving activity just opened a whole new line of expenses. So learning to budget will be tough, I guess.

Maybe if I find my daytimer I can start recording all of my purchases each day and give myself some perspective! I'll check under the bed first.

MONDO is going well, as well. I certainly never saw myself running a magazine of this scope, so it's exciting in a new, surprising way. I submitted a comic last week, so my internet fame has begun! I'm considering writing reviews of the shows I've seen, but mostly I just want to continue with the comics - I'm not a confidant article writer, especially not when I see the calibre of content we have up already. I'm trying to shove my nose into the whole magazine more deeply, though, do more general editing and make more noise as an E-i-C to compensate for not really participating otherwise...

Hmm.

I started this entry with the intent of simply listing all the cool shit I've been doing, but it got way off topic, eh? Rest assured, I've been doing cool shit. Maybe I'll take the time over lunch at work someday this week to list it? We'll see. Till then, I'm going to try and find my damn daytimer.

Thank you all for your job-hunting suggestions, BTW - they were honestly appreciated. Thankfully one of the jobs that I applied for at the end of April actually got back in touch with me, and I have been hired by The Printing House. They've made me sign a nondisclosure agreement, but it's not a very interesting job anyways, so don't worry...

In other news, I graduated today. Shabam!

So hopefully now i can kind of settle into this working routine, clean my chaotic room, actually make some art and, y'know, see my friends again! I'm gonna go rev down and digest my congrats-you-graduated-dinner and I'll see you all in the real world!

Once again I am pimping Volume in my LJ.

I'm a nerdy older sister.

My brother and his band Volume are playing next friday at Loon's open mic night. It's a roncesvalles bar, up near Dundas, and I don't know yet what time they're expecting to play, but it'd be awesome if I could bring a couple open-minded listeners to be a support crew. He and his buddies are still largely underage, and so it's not easy for them to bring their own croud to a licensed bar 'n all. They're largely a classic-rock inspired three-piece, and they do covers as well as quite a lot of original stuff. Somewhere in the archives of this LJ is a link to their NMC website, as well.

Anyways, yes, if you're around that friday come see these kids play!
So I draw henna at wonderland now. For a bit. It pays shit, guys, I need another job. Whose workplace is hiring??

Moved, unpacking, broke, no job yet, tired, and my kite got run over by a car. Good roommates though, nice neighbourhood, future'll be good, hate this limbo period though. Anyone got a paying gig that'll put me above the red again? Hit me up.

Well I'm done university.


Since finishing, I have gotten drunk at my class's art reception, seen Do Make Say Think and The Books, rocked out at Karaoke, and avoided laundry like the devil himself.

Wheeee!

My bedroom curtain fell down. Since I move out in three weeks, I feel like it's not worth dragging my dad and his drill back up to fix them... but I really didn't sleep well last night (so bright!) so maybe I'm going to have to...

Stupid curtain. What the heck, eh?

Also, next art project (to run concurrently with the cellphones and sleeping boys):

       watercolour portraits of male metalheads

I feel my practice is too feminine. Time to use it to make comments about performative gender! But not my gender. Other people's gender. I'm not THAT good an artist yet!

So if you consider yourself to be "metal" in any way, get all metalled up and meet me at the next show I make it out to! I will happily send you a digital file or print of the final painting (which won't be too big - probably 9" x 12" or even smaller) as payment and just imagine the karma! It'll be a shoulders-and-face shot, so sorry, I won't be plugging your favourite bands with this work. So yeah, drop me a comment and pass the news along - I'd like to do a pretty big series here, ten or fifteen portraits total.

Thanks!

PS: any other sleepy boys willing to pose for me in the city?

I'm just crossposting this from the
yorku
  community.

Hey, I just wanted to let everyone in the community know that MONDOmagazine, the late, great Winters College paper, is not nearly as dead as advertised! We are alive and kicking, here on the internet, at www.mondomagazine.net!





MONDOmagazine is also looking for submitters! Contact us via our website, or by emailing us at editor@mondomagazine.net, if you want to write, draw or photograph things for us to publish!

Em and I watched The Brothers Grimm.

Now, I love Terry Gilliam. More than popcorn. And he's done some great films. But I swear he's going senile.

That said, the mirror effect was DAMN COOL, and yes, I jumped at every potentially jumpy moment. Gilliam's got his audience by the short ones, if they bother to sit through it at all.
I have bizarre moods. Tonight was a surprisingly productive sulk.

I put up more art!

I did this watercolour triptych for my first painting project this term:




I'm submitting it to VASA's downtown juried fourth year show, but don't wait for that! Head up to York tomorrow (friday) evening for our fabulous (or at least it had better damn well be fabulous...) Open House! I hear there's wine.

I have to do more of those small cellphone paintings, which is fine, but I also have another two projects to do this term (oh, four weeks? three?) and as my painting teacher just... doesn't... seem to care.... I'm finding it hard to dig up inspiration, and motivation, for these future projects. I'm doing stuff in print that's all blurred out and I'm tempted to do similar work in painting, but to be honest, wouldn't know how to go about it. So I'll get back to you on these future projects as they manifest.

That said, I need cellphone reference photos! Who can look cranky in public? I'll meet you with my camera.
PS: who's writing the treatise on canadian patriotism as channeled/spawned by CBC Radio 3?

Katherine's finished with the guestbook from our show so I'm flipping through it, re-reading all the comments, and people just react so hilariously to my pillows.... :D

"Rachel, way to obsess about and expose our most primal and basic needs..."

"...they are both evocative and sexual..."

"...are you keeping those pillows afterwards?"

"Sensational!"

"LOVE THE PILLOWS!!"

"The satin cushions are very engaging."

"I thought it was a play on the term/phrase 'dirty pillows'!"

"Very original and sexually stimulating."

Everyone wanted to buy one, but only two people left contact info. Makes me aware that I should really have a business card available at future shows... also, I should paint more pillows.

If anyone knows any stores that'll take them on a consignment basis and are comfortable selling fine art pieces with three-digit prices, please, please let me know!

And now for my favourite entry as pertaining to my work:

"Have you considered doing comics, you have this style that seems very unique to graphic novel storytelling - the sequencing of moments and the emphasis put on awareness of surroundings and emotions -great focus on details. Anyways, I'm sure you've considered comics and you should have put up more of those..."

SHE GOT IT. It's the only comics-related reference in the whole book. Go figure!

So yes, now I feel better again about my art. Which is good. Cause I have been in the print studio for a total of 15 hours over three days, with not-nearly-enough progress, and I now have absorbed enough chemicals that my skin smells like printing ink.

Mmmm, printing ink.....

This is part of a series of small watercolours about people on cellphones in public. I've got another in the works and a few more reference photos to play with, so hopefully it keeps going.





The following two are sketches in preparation for a 3-5 drawing series on boys sleeping. I have very accomodating friends.

I am dating a boy who can re-install windows eight times without swearing.

You have no idea how rare and valuable a trait that kind of patience is.

Mind you, I just sat on the phone LISTENING to him re-install windows eight times. So I guess I know patience when I see it.

On another note, I have to draw people in bed for class, so who's willing to be photographed in bed? Drop me a line and we'll work out a date and time. I can't promise to render you large-scale, but at the very least you'll become a preparatory sketch, which, as Em said, still counts as art!

Also, I need another three painting project proposals. So far I've painted: 1 panel of people not talking in an elevator; 2 panels of people not talking on the bus, 6 panels of someone waiting for something, and 3 panels of people not talking on a couch (still in progress). I think the key word is "awkward" or "uncomfortable". I have one plan involving an unsolicited held door, but otherwise I'm out of ideas. So throw some at me! Or suggest angsty songs with narratives. Those are AWESOME.

#39:

My washing machine is in the basement of my apartment building, and I have to admit that our relationship is unavoidably framed by the distance between us. I'm always short on patience by the time I've carried all my laundry to the elevator, and then down the hall and up the stairs that follow. To be honest, I put off my time with the washing machine until I'm forced to rush through the whole experience, and I think it's done nothing but create tension between us. Maybe, if I just set aside more time, the machine and I would get along better? But it isn't all me - I would be much more inclined to spend time with a machine that didn't cost me $2 for the basic service. I feel sometimes like my economic status becomes a barrier between us, and I can go weeks without seeing my washer simply because I can't afford to. So, maybe--perhaps--I like to think, at least, that I'm not the only reason this relationship isn't working.

You know, I have to admit, I'm seriously thinking about moving on. I know there are other washers out there, at the bottoms of other apartment buildings, or even, some of them, in rooms of their own. Maybe it's time to take the leap?

Hmm....

Well, my grandfather passed away last Monday. The funeral is tomorrow (today? Saturday.) and then life kinda begins again. I don't really know how to talk about it yet - I haven't really processed it, so I don't really want to "work through it" yet with anyone, despite offers of help, liquor and comfort food/shopping. I'm hoping to get through the backlog of work I've created by missing class/being unable to focus and then start to deal with this.

Of course, at the very same time, Robin's decided to show up and start dating me, which has been lovely and conveniently timed to coincide with some of my loneliest moments this year. The only tragic part is that he resides in Oakville, and I'm short on travel time while I finish the term. I'm sure you'll all hear about how that works out. 

Hopefully I get my head screwed back on soon, as I have a lot of painting transactions to finalize, homework to catch up on, MONDOwork to delve into, and housework to feel bad about avoiding. o_O...

Onwards, I suppose!

It makes me so happy to look up Terry Pratchett's IMDB page and find:

Miscellaneous Crew - filmography

Discworld (1995) (VG) (yelling at people)

Something is now all right with the world.

I am:
H.G. Wells
The first major literary talent to make himself at home in the science fiction field, greatly expanding its popularity.


Which science fiction writer are you?

So I ... uh.. disappeared while working on that show. But it went amazingly well! Katherine and I are just wrapping up after-show-bill-counting and getting the (full!) comments book photocopied, and I'm photoshopping all the photos we took of the installation and reception, and then I'll post it all in my flickr and link you snazzy friends from there!

Why are you snazzy, you ask? Because I couldn't believe how many of you made it up to my reception on teh nastiest winter night of the year! And how many more stopped in and left kind words in the book! You guys are amazing and left Katherine and I feeling very, very warm and fuzzy about our work :)

So thank you all - I can't explain how scared I was about this and how amazing I feel about it all now! Thank you all so much.

....so, MONDO has been continuing, unmentioned by me here (which is silly! I should pimp it constantly!) and it's getting bigger and bigger each week! Miles and I just finished the fifth update since we went online, so pop on over and take a look - you might find something that really speaks to you.

If you DON'T, then what you need to do is get writing! Put together a music review, propose an interview, write an opinion column or a recipe or a comic, and get your voice on our website! We are just aching to publish your work. Seriously.

In other mundane news, I picked up a shareware program called Neat Image to take the digital noise out of my photos, and man, is it ever amazing when it works! I mean, sometimes it doesn't - but when it does, ho-lee. Magic!

....and yeah. So keep an eye on this space for photos, and read MONDO, and submit, and think of me as I move a sleeping bag into the print studios for the rest of the term!
Please stop by! There will be food and refreshments at the reception! Shrimp riiiiiing! Hell, I might even bake!

Guys! lookit my tattoo!



It hurt like a bitch! But it's done!

For tattoo nerds, it was done by Eric (erik?) at New Tribe, on Queen west. Took 2.5 hours of excruciating pain. Why did none of you smack me upside the head when I proposed detailed blackwork up my spine onto my ribs? Though perhaps, perhaps that pain was worth it. Anyways, now it's healing! and ITCHY.

Em and I have started running!

That's right kids, we are wearing running shoes, sweatpants, quik-dry shirts and other such hi-tech gear, and we are beating ourselves into shape!

Wish us luck. Anyone who's severely out of shape want a rather pathetic running buddy? I'm currently on one-minute-running, two-minutes-walking.

Also, I had my first free Pilates warmup today!

Yeah, Em's a pretty sweet roommate catch.

Adam won't be living this far north of bloor, it seems...

....so I guess... I'll be moving.

I'm reluctant about this, but it could be really good for me. I'm probably much better off downtown. Anyone have any toronto house-hunting tips? Pass 'em my way.

I thought they would try and play DOWN the sexy side, but no, they cast DANIEL CRAIG. Not that Asriel gets THAT much screen time in The Golden Compass, but... y'know...

*swoon*



What can I say, really? They might butcher it - it wouldn't be hard - and I'd rather people read the books - but I'm still very, very, very excited.

At 1:15AM, I am pushed to wonder to myself, what was Bach referencing in his mind when he set about writing down Toccata and Fugue in Dm?

It's incredibly epic.

I wouldn't know what to visualize to it - the content is really nonliteral. Except I'm sure there are trees. Big, dark trees. I kind of link it to a Friedrich painting, really.
Ta-da! See ya'll in pain in a week!

It's a new year. I'm 21 for 37 more days. I'm drunk. I drank so much baileys. Me me me me me. I have to code all day tomorrow, goddammit. Miles, you're coding too. But I'm not coming down there. I'll explain it over the phone or something.

New Year's Resolutions:

1) Do lots! I'm happiest when I'm doing stuff (coding, painting, sewing, reading, even writing) so the more I do, the happier I'll be, right?
2) Take time off. I also like movies. I should really rent more! And I should read recreationally. And take days for sleeping in and organizing my photos, cause I love doing that. Like, tagging them and stuff.
3) Organize usefully. Not in a way that's beyond my ability to remember.
4) Keep up on the basic news. It makes conversation a lot easier, and, I mean, I do care, a bit.
5) Eat HEALTHIER. I hate having months where I know I'm living off of cheese, bacon and coke. My stomach hates them too.

I guess in the new year I want to be proud of myself, and I also want to reach out more to other people. I think it's possible to do both - I'm gonna find out.

Other things I'm going to have to do in this new year:
1) Graduate! (AAAAAAAAAAAAUUUGGGHHH!! the real world!!!!)
2) Find a new roommate. Em, I'm gonna miss yoooou T_T;; Maybe Adam'll give in and live north of Bloor with me?
3) Get a job. Any job that'll pay rent, to start, and then I need to start finding ways to make money doing something I like. But for starters, let's pay rent.
4) TRAVEL. Goddammit, Toronto's awesome, but I need to see some trees. And distant family. And distant friends!
5) MONDO. I'm committed, it's a big part of my life, I'm gonna make it awesome. For all that I sometimes want to kill him, Miles has been instrumental to getting this shit going, and I'm confidant that, beyond his dislike of code, he'll continue to be 'that other motivated guy' on the project. *kick* Which is awesome.

I don't really know where to start here. This year has been CRAZY. I thought '05 was nuts, I thought '04 was crazy, and even '03 seemed a little off the hook, but this one's been just as bizarre, even if I didn't leave the province. Actually, the farthest I went this year was Niagara Falls! That's, well, that's just nutso. But I guess I've been farther in other ways, doing things I didn't predict myself doing, and surviving the inevitable consequences. Also, growing my hair long. Very long. So I guess I'm impressed (and a tad shocked) at myself this past year, and so as long as I remember to, like, take responsibility and deal with things, I should be able to avoid major self-loathing. Also, while I sometimes continue to have anxiety attacks about it, I think I've got a pretty solid base of good friends around me. I really should reach out to them more. And not worry so much.

Having now been single for 14 months, I can attest to two things: 1) being single means being generally guilt free, which is fantastic! except... 2) being single means that any clingy, affectionate, nuzzly moments end up guilt-ridden, at least on some level. So yeah. I kind of feel like I've worked out everything I'm gonna work out by being single right now, and I'm quite ready for the next fluffy giddy cute wave of relationship-ness. Preferably with someone who will drive to St. John's with me.

I also feel like I need to branch out a bit more. I hope I get some neat jobs and internships and volunteer positions over the next year, and maybe find some places to settle in. I also am interested to find out how good I am at holding a job for a long time. I haven't had long-term employment since Cotton Ginny, and man I hated that by the end. I wonder if I have the attention span for a long-term job ANYWHERE, so I'm kind of excited to find out. Also, I mean, I do want to be an artist, so I suppose I should find an art crowd to mingle with at openings. Also, make more art.

.... I didn't really think too hard about this entry, and I'm not sure why I wrote it, but it seems to be publishable, so ta-da! Happy new year, I'm drunk and stoic, and getting good at it!

I do want to apologize to everyone I snarked on in the month leading up to christmas. I lost my crutch and the holiday season hit me unprepared, as always, but that was no reason to beat the rest of you up over it! Besides, friends are what made the good parts great.  Yadayadayada, sorry for being a bitch. It's over now, and all I have to survive is new year's eve, which I intend to navigate in the same fashion as last year: through a wine and liquor-induced haze. If I host the party, though, I can sleep in my own bed and manage the hangover at home with some OJ and block-out blinds.

Before new years, though, i'm going to have to correct this sleep schedule misalignment. I will start by moving towards bed now, as well as setting an alarm so I get OUT of bed tomorrow MORNING, not afternoon.

All wonderful resolutions, I'm sure. Goodnight!

I have begun tentative MONDOsite design (yeah, I know it's blue right now, but it's going to be a million times swankier once we launch!) and I want your feedback! These are gonna be fairly big, so beware.
First, my examples:

So this would be the "home" or "splash" page, where you'd start. We'd have images and captions for a variety of newly updated articles, starting with what we'd figure to be the most exciting, and moving into reviews, shorter features, as well as favourite opinion columns or sex columns or what have you.

The main idea is that the top and sidebar will wrap around all of our content. So that photo will serve as a "cover" image to MONDO. In theory, we're thinking we'll switch it up monthly.



This is the same layout with a different photo, which changes the colour of the sidebar and the section headers, but nothing else.



Back to the blue, though, cause it was awesome. THIS is a section splash page, in this example it's the Arts section - so now you'll notice the sidebar has expanded to include arts-specific choices, like top features and as such. That'll switch up and become more section-specific as we have content to link to. For example, we'll probably throw the sex columns into the Lifestyle sidebar, because people will come looking specifically for those. The spread here is a splash page of the most recently updated Arts columns, agan with the most exciting at the top, and so on and so forth.



Now, this is an article in the arts section, so it's again within the specific Arts sidebar, but it's just the article. Don't mind the latin, that's just filler text. So I'm thinking that the three-column layout with the wraparound text and a few nice images (maybe we can click them to see bigger ones?) will be nice. Also, I intend to have the author's name be linked to a list of all the articles they've written, so if someone decides that Rachel Kahn writes hilarious articles, they can look up and see what else i"ve written, in any section. Hopefully this'll encourage people who visit us only for music or film to explore our other sections.




So, questions for you guys! How do I make the sidebar more exciting? What about the top bar? Is it easy to do wraparound text in CSS? How much of a bitch will it be to change the image monthly? What other features does the website need? Fill me in! I'm crossposting this
mondo_online
as well, and I hope that with everyone voicing their opinions, we'll get some excellent feedback and end up with an already-swanky website to launch with!

Anyways, keep writing and sending in your articles, and we'll see you all on the 1st!

~Rachel
